description:
Hope the training goes smoothly and that it is now facilitated by the fact that it is a little spring!!

A varied week in terms of training, as the coach includes, among other things, a hill run with different lengths where you can work with different speeds and range of motion in your run based on the length of the hill . Thursday features foundational short intervals where you run your for-the-season comfortably fast pace; whatever you do will be a good transition to everything else.

Find your flow; and DO NOT push HARD on the short intervals.

Sunday the long session rolls on as usual and now with 28 km as the target; at your leisurely pace!

Today it will be downhill! First warm up with a distance jog that takes you to a hill that should ideally be long enough that you can get in up to 60 seconds of running uphill at a comfortably fast pace. Fairly steep so you can run the entire 60-second stretch uphill at an ok speed.

Once in place at the hill, you do some mobility and running training.

Running training; 2 x 20 meters in the bottom counterslope of the hill.

Basic exercises; low skip - high knee lift heel kicks and then you can if you want to add any more exercise (check out the video). Walking rest down the running training distance. Think about good posture and active steps.

Then we start the downhill session itself, and it will be a session where we will work with both longer and shorter slopes.

The purpose of the session will be to work on running technique, running strength and fitness but also a little different "pressure in the step" during the session.

We start with some 60 second (takes approx. 60 seconds uphill) long hills where we work with good technique but without pushing too much. We run "nice and controlled" uphill.

Good to take the first long hill as part of the warm-up.

When we then switch to an intermediate variant in the time uphill, it will be a 40-second running time uphill and now you try to increase the pressure in the step a notch but not tougher than that on the closing short "20 second downhills" we can increase pressure, range of motion and posture another notch.

The rest between the slopes is that you stop and rest for a few seconds where we turn, and then we jog down to the start and take a few seconds' rest before starting again.

On the longer slopes, the jog down can preferably be a little faster, but on the shorter slopes, the jog down can be really calm and preferably also a little the beginning and end of "the transport is brought down".

Between the changes of the hill length, you can also take a few seconds of extra standing rest below the hill so that you are ready to push a notch more on the next variation of the hill length.

Your target picture today will be to run the following number of hills in the respective time length up:

4 x 60 seconds

5 x 40 seconds

5 x 20 seconds

After the hill run, you wind down with a leisurely jog followed by some form of stretching.

Start today's session with a warm-up distance at a leisurely pace of around 2.5 km, followed by short softening mobility. Then a running training component with some exercises over 2 x 30 meters. Also feel free to do some coordination to get your pulse and speed up before the interval part starts.

The layout of the interval session will be 200 meter intervals, divided into series with 4 intervals in each series. The rest is 30 seconds of "standing rest" between intervals, and then you take 60 seconds of standing/walking rest between each set. The goal picture will be 16 intervals in total, so 4 x 4 x 200 meters.

Really short rest today, which means that the speed should not be pressured or high, but the short rest ensures a good conditioning effect and transfer to your marathon pace will be included supermarginal :)

The program (and you) should continue to focus on foundational cardio training, but the goal is of course also to get your legs moving without risking injuries through running too fast.

Run through the session with "one gear left" , and focus on your technique. Good stately posture and active step. Let the drive of the arms help with the speed without being tempted to sprint for the sake of it!

Target speed around 4.10-4.15 min/km, which gives around 50-51 seconds per 200 meters.

End the session as usual with jogging mobility.

To get the week's strength in, we run a separate home session without running. Light easy warm-up "around the house", bicycle or other, and then a little lighter strength than usual just to keep the muscles moving and not lose the continuity we built up through strength every week.

26 km long run. Long but still not maxed out in distance and only your relatively "calm" long run speed for the day. Shorten if the body is worn. The whole is most important - and we have several more weekends to work on the long run foundation before the marathon.
